Name: Sarcophagus of Pairwsekher
Description: Sarcophagus of Pairwsekher, "divine father" of the Temple of Mut in Karnak. It consists of the sarcophagus itself, an outer lid and an inner lid that would have been in direct contact with the mummy. Its iconography and decoration are similar to those of other sarcophagi of the era. The outer lid shows the deceased's face topped with a long wig that falls down over his shoulders and over the usekh collar. The outer surface of the sarcophagus is covered with funerary divinities alternating with hieroglyphic inscriptions that mention the deceased or the gods. These include winged scarabs,  Thoth, Isis, Hathor, Bastet, and Maat. Inside the sarcophagus the divinities and funerary genies accompany the deceased and march in procession towards the god Osiris, who is shown inside his naos and is attended by female divinities.
